The most likely diagnosis is acute ascending cholangitis (

). The presence of cholangitis is heralded by the onset of the Charcot triad (fever, jaundice, and right-upper-quadrant abdominal pain) or Reynolds pentad (Charcot triad plus hypotension and altered mental status), as seen in this patient. Diagnostic imaging revealing signs of biliary obstruction further supports the diagnosis. Cholangitis is potentially life-threatening. Initial risk stratification, based on severity and multiplicity of involvement of other organ systems, is used to guide treatment of acute ascending cholangitis. In this patient, aggressive crystalloid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy targeting gram-negative

should be administered. Identified common bile duct stones should be removed urgently, with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography in patients with cholangitis, after which elective cholecystectomy should be performed during the initial hospitalization or within 2 weeks to reduce the risk of complications. In patients who are not surgical candidates, endoscopic sphincterotomy can be performed to facilitate the passage of additional common bile duct stones.
